g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
. These examples differ by context. Examples in
other chapters include transformations in energy, urban, building, industrial, transport, and land
systems, changes in behaviour and social practices, as well as transf
. Coordinated policy mixes would need to coordinate multiple actors
corporate actors, institutions and infrastructure actors
decarbonisation and shift pathways towards sustainability. Shifts in one country may spill over to other
countries. Shifting development pathways can jointly support mitigation and adaptat
explore the risks of high complexity and potential delay attached to shifting development pathways
The literature identifies a broad set of enabling conditions that can both foster shifting
development pathways and accelerated mitigation, along five categories
). Policy integration is a necessary component of shifting development pathways, addressing
multiple objectives. To this aim, mobilising a range of policies is preferable to single policy instruments
. Governance for climate mitigation and shifting development
pathways is enhanced when tailored to national and local contexts. Improved institutions and
governance enable ambitious climate action and help bridge implementati
). Given that strengthening institutions may be a long term endeavour, it needs attention
. Accelerated mitigation and shifting development pathways necessitates both re
emissions technologies and systems and to provide
additional resources to overcome current financial barriers. (
term to close the finance gap
. At the national level, public finance for
actions promoting the SDG agenda helps broaden the scope of mitigation (
). Changes in behaviour and lifestyles are important to move beyond mitigation as
d when supporting shifts to more sustainable development pathways will
mational changes are likely to be
more acceptable if rooted in the development aspirations of the economy and society within which they
enabler of deeper ambition for accelerated mitigation,
costs and benefits and how these are shared as per social contracts, national policy
and international agreements. Transition pathways have distributional consequences
changes in employment and economic structure (
just transition concept has become an international focal point tying together social movements, trade
unions, and other key stakeholders to e
nsure equity is better accounted for in low
Effectiveness of cooperative action and the perception of fairness of such arrangements are closely
related, in that pathways that prioritise equity and allow broad stakeholders p
broader consensus for the transformational change implied by deeper mitigation efforts (
). Hence, equity is a concept that is instrumentally important
s that the immediate tasks are to broaden and deepen mitigation
term if the global community is to deliver emission reductions at the scale required to keep
temperature well below 2°C and pursue efforts at 1.5°C. Deepening mitigation means more
decarbonisation. Shifting development pathways to increased sustainability (SDPS) broadens the scope
of mitigation. Putting the enabling conditions above in place supports both. Depending on context, some
enabling conditions such as shifting behavio
ur may take time to establish, underscoring the importance
of early action. Other enabling conditions, such as improved access to financing, can be put in place in
a relatively short time frame, and can yield results rapidly.
